awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Coeval Degenerates Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
The lowest mass stars in the Milky Way galaxy, K and M type stars ("cool dwarfs") are the most abundant, long-lived stars in the galaxy. It is important for astronomers to be able to precisely measure their ages in order to help answer the questions: "What is the fossil record of the assembly of our galaxy from the first stars to the present?" and "How diverse are planetary systems?" Cool dwarfs are sufficiently long-lived that they carry a record of star formation and chemical evolution over the entire history of the galaxy. Furthermore, Earth-sized transiting planets in the habitable zones of M dwarfs are easier to detect than planets orbiting Sun-like stars, but the ages of their host stars are much more difficult to measure. A research collaboration between the University of Hawai'i and Boston University will develop stellar rotation-based tools to infer precise ages for old (>4 billion year-old) K and M type stars. They will do this by studying wide binary star systems containing both a white dwarf (WD) star and a star still on the main sequence (MS) of stellar evolution. Rotation can be measured in the main-sequence star, and an independent age of both stars can be inferred using the white dwarf. The investigators will also directly engage high-school students in scientific research through the HISTAR program at the University of Hawai'i. Students will have the opportunity to experience ownership over an individual stellar system, while working to contribute to the broader goal of building a timeline of galactic events and planetary system evolution. Students will work with data obtained on the summits of Hawaii's mountains, and interact with colleagues at Boston University.

The spin-down of stars with time is a promising age-dating tool, but can only be used if the relationship between age and rotation can be properly calibrated. Currently, a primary limitation is the lack of empirical anchors of known age for these old, low-mass stars.  This project will leverage wide WD+MS binaries to provide rotation and age calibrators.  Total white dwarf ages are the combination of the time spent cooling as a dead core and the progenitor system's hydrogen and helium burning lifetimes. Both quantities are readily inferred from existing models and initial-final mass relations.  These binaries provide the leverage to extend period-age relations out to the age of the galactic disk. Gaia DR2 has enabled the identification over one thousand bright (G < 15 mag), nearby (< 200 pc) WD+MS systems widely separated enough to have never interacted. First, the researchers will use ground-based archival light curves to measure rotation periods of the main-sequence companions and spectroscopically characterize the white dwarfs to determine total system ages. In total, it will develop a sample of >50-100 calibration systems. Second, this proposal will explore systematic uncertainties in the ability of white dwarfs to deliver reliable old ages by studying coeval pairs of wide WD+WD binaries. Finally, it will confront existing models for stellar spin down with empirical anchors, and develop the first calibrated period-age relation for old (>4 Gyr), low-mass (<0.8 solar-mass) stars.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stellar ages are one of the most difficult properties to measure, and yet also provide some of the most interesting constraints: precise ages allow us to place stellar and planetary systems in a chronological context. This program focused on some of the most difficult stars to age-date: slowly evolving, low-mass stars that make up the majority of stars in the Milky Way. For these stars, the use of “rotation period-age” relations appears to be one of the only viable methods for measuring precise ages, and takes advantage of the observation that stars tend to be born rapidly rotating and spin down as they age. However, this period-age relationship is the consequence of poorly understood stellar physics, and so the definition of precise period-age relations requires calibrating systems where both the stellar age and rotation period are known. 

 

In this work we primarily used wide white dwarf (WD) - main sequence (MS) binary star systems as our calibrators. Stars in these systems are coeval, and the WD component can be age-dated using WD cooling models: a measurement of the star’s current luminosity and mass allows us to infer the time it has spent cooling since exhausting its fuel; when coupled to a relationship between the WD’s current and initial stellar mass and models of the evolutionary lifetimes of stars of different masses, we can infer a total age of the star. Because the system is coeval, this age can be applied to the MS companion. We measure the rotation period of the MS companion using photometric rotational modulation from surface magnetic spots. 

 

This program was divided into two parts. The first effort was designed to test the robustness of the WD cooling models using wide WD-WD pairs: we measured cooling and system ages for each component individually and tested whether there was consistency between the two age inferences. This exercise taught us several things: 1) that the errors on the ages of WDs inferred this way can be underestimated, especially for the more massive WDs, and 2) that a significant fraction of systems (~30%) have ages that are inconsistent with each other in a way that suggests these systems are likely the remnants of triple stars systems. 

 

The second component of our program addressed the WD-MS pairs and MS rotational evolution. We found marked differences in the rotational behavior with time of stars that have only a convective envelope versus fully convective stars. Fully convective stars appear to undergo an early and relatively rapid phase of spin down, making them appear old and slowly rotating when they are in fact still relatively young. We attribute this rapid spin down to a change in the internal structure of stars when they become fully convective, which increases the efficiency of magnetic field generation and results in efficient spin down. 

 

Our existing spin-down models appear to naturally reproduce the behavior in the fully convective stars, once the change in structure is properly included. However, stars just shy of being fully convective continue to pose a challenge to our existing models. Real stars appear to spin down more slowly at early times (1-2 Gyr) than expected from standard rotational evolution models. As part of this program, we investigated partially convective stars in the Praesepe open cluster (leveraging the fact that these stars also represent a coeval population) and found that this epoch of “stalled” rotational evolution coincides with a period of intense surface magnetic activity, seen as an abundance of starspots. We posited that both the stalled spin down and the increased activity are due to internal rotational shear in the stars that help drive a magnetic dynamo and signals that the transport of angular momentum to the stellar surface is more complicated than typically assumed.

 

We have therefore learned that 1) the WD cooling models are generally robust, but do require more careful treatment of the uncertainty on the ages one infers from them, 2) that the spin-down of stars appears to be rapid in fully convective objects, driven by the changes in their internal structures, and 3) that the rotational evolution of partially convective stars is likely complicated by internal angular momentum transport. In all cases, it requires a more nuanced application of the age-dating tools when attempting to measure stellar ages for these low-mass stellar systems. 

 

This grant supported summer research experiences for high school students through the HISTAR program for the entirety of its duration. Students from across the Hawaiian island chain participate in talks and guided mini-research programs during a one-week summer program and may then be paired with researchers to complete a science fair project over the following semesters. This grant provided direct monetary support for participants to travel to the one-week summer research programs and supported a series of lectures delivered at HISTAR programs by the researchers.
